moves.4... exd5 5. Bg5: This is played so White doesn't end up with a bad bishop when pawn e3 is played
moves.5... Be7 6. e3 O-O 7. Qc2:
Not book move per se, more common is Bd3. 
White can play 7.Bd3 and later play Qb3
moves.7... c6 8. Bd3 h6 9. Bf4: This cuts into Blacks position than retreating the Bishop to h4. Later on in the middle game, this Bishop attacks Black's back rank on b8.
moves.9... Be6 10. h3: Creating an air luft for the King and Bishop
moves.13. Rab1:
?
a mistake on my part. Ill preparing the minor attack pawn-b4.
moves.15. a4:
!
Now White is preventing Black's minor pawn attack!
moves.15... Bxc3:
?
Black will now have chronic dark square weaknesses in the middle and endgame.
moves.18... Nd6 19. Rfc1 Rc8 20. b4 Nd7 21. Bh: And here I pondered on 22. Ng6+ for clearance to capture 23. BxNd6. But that wouldn't work out to well for my light square bishop.
moves.24... Ra8:
?
I had anticipated Qxa5 and minor pieces exchange on the d-file to follow.
moves.25. e4: I did this 1) to objectively to create a lever and 2) with Bishop d2 in mind to protect the a5-pawn.
moves.25... Nf6 26. Be3:
Now I reneged to protect my d-pawn!
Black can force exchanges on the e4 square and black can capture on d4 with check!
moves.26... Rxa5 27. Bf2: Now I am moving away from the treacherous e8-Rook!
moves.27... Qa8 28. Nxc6:
This constitutes a combination, but is not forced. That's important to note because Black can decline and play 28...Qc8 or 28...Rc8.
Clearance and pawn fork tactic.

Minor piece sacrifice. Not sure what to grade it
Instead of defending the a-pawn I had moved towards a central attack.
It was about this time I notice my King's Fortress is filled with gaping holes and prone to ...Bxh3.

gameName: Queen's Gambit Decline: Orthodox Carlsbad exchange. minor pawn attack for White
